Text:
Miro is an excellent and exceptional tool for myself and also my customers 
Its an amazing tool for documentation and visual thinking 
Allows teams from different locations to interact and share ideas
Miro usability and flexibility is the reason why we decided to use it 
It is simple and easy to adapt the application 
It supports powerful tools i love most such as sticky notes mapping brainstorming polls etc 
One can comfortably use it from any device as it supports mobile version desktop version and browser version 
Miro is not expensive compared to other alternatives out there
One of the challenges is that sometimes navigation isnt good with zooming in and out and also browsing is a little bit cumbersome when there is too much content on the same board
nn_summary: Users appreciate Miro for its collaborative planning and discovery features, making complex discussions simple and accessible for teams in various fields. However, they find connecting shapes to be buggy and wish for better integration with PowerPoint or other export solutions.

Text:
Lack of visual communication Traditional communication methods like emails or chats can sometimes make it difficult to convey complex ideas or visualize a concept FigJam solves this problem by providing an easytouse whiteboarding tool that allows teams to quickly create visual representations of their ideas and share them with others
FigJam is a collaborative online whiteboarding tool created by Figma that allows teams to work together in realtime to brainstorm plan and visualize ideas One of the best things about FigJam is its ease of use and intuitive interface which makes it simple for even nondesigners to quickly create diagrams flowcharts wireframes and other types of visual content
sometimes UI could be complicated if youre a user that are not familiar with the FIGMA infinite canvas system that you can scroll a lot and not find the end Aside from that is great
nn_summary: Users appreciate Miro for its collaboration features, enabling teams to work together on presentations and designs more efficiently than with InDesign or PowerPoint. Miro is particularly helpful for remote team members, though some users may initially feel intimidated. While it offers more design flexibility, users may need to be creative to achieve desired results.

Text:
Think its impossible to create a successful solo business without coding and an audience Think again I did it and heres how I did it to earn my first dollars here  a gift is waiting for you in the last tweet 
Before we begin
When I won 2500 here
 I had an audience of 500 followers
 I didnt know how to code
 I didnt know anything about Twitter
I did
So did you
Now heres how I did it 
 First you need a brilliant idea It doesnt have to be groundbreaking just something youre passionate about Remember youre building this solo so youll need that passion to fuel your journey
 Once you have your idea its time to build without coding I used webflow to create my website and app without any coding knowledge Its incredibly userfriendly with a plethora of customizable templates to suit your business
webflow  Organize your thoughts and plan your content using NotionHQ As a solopreneur I found this to be the perfect tool for managing my tasks jotting down ideas and creating content outlines Plus its super easy to use
webflow NotionHQ  Find your niche and target audience You dont need a massive audience to succeedjust a group of dedicated engaged followers who love your work Focus on connecting with them and providing value
webflow NotionHQ  Share your work and gather feedback Join communities like IndieHackers ProductHunt and relevant Facebook groups to find likeminded people who can give you insights and encouragement
webflow NotionHQ IndieHackers ProductHunt  Set up a business model that works for you From subscriptions and memberships to onetime purchases find a revenue stream that fits your goals and caters to your audiences needs
webflow NotionHQ IndieHackers ProductHunt  Educate yourself Attend webinars read articles and listen to podcasts to stay uptodate with the latest trends and strategies You dont need a formal education to succeed just a curious mind

nn_summary: A user discussed how to improve the UI/UX of a website called LoseTheVery, which helps find concise adjectives. They identified three main flaws: messiness, inconsistency in design, and cramped elements. Using Figma, they suggested decluttering by removing unnecessary newsletter elements, adding more whitespace for better visual separation, improving button design for consistency, and simplifying typography by using only two typefaces.

There are a few flaws though there is no offline mode the AI features that I dont use cannot be deactivated is is not as fast as a native app like apple notessimplenoteetc there is no real pensupport for drawing and sketching the app logs me out frequently and that feeling of having too many eggs in one basket
One improvement that would be great on iOS when I share a youtube video to a notion database via share sheet the URL is the title It would be great if the title was the video title and the URL was an embedded video in the content Adding Tags when sharing would also be helpful
nn_summary: User enjoys using Notion for note-taking and syncing between devices, but has issues with the lack of offline mode, AI features not being deactivated, and the app logging them out frequently. They suggest adding offline mode, pen support for drawing and sketching, and a better sharing experience for iOS users.

Text:
It allows me to put all the pieces of my project in one place so nothing gets lost When you have an evolving project with research and numerous iterations it helps to be able to see all the info in one place and makes it easier for others to understand the full picture 
 
I also use miro to share out work and do critiques It is easy to have collaborators follow me on the board while I am presenting I will generally share my screen while presenting but it can be hard to see small details so having others in the board helps with this There are comment and sticky notes available for peers to leave feedback too
The board is endless and I can fill it with as much content as I want There is a timer and you can set yourself to be followed around the board which makes critiques easier It is extremely easy to add arrow connections Overall its simple and easy to use
Miro has cool features that are somewhat hidden so I didnt realize they existed for awhile Because boards can fill up easily it helps to share a link for a frame directly and it can be done but its hidden behind a meatball menu There are stickers which come in handy but are hidden behind a plus on the sidebar
nn_summary: The user appreciates the ability to organize their project in one place and share it with collaborators, as well as the ability to add comments and sticky notes. They also appreciate the endless board feature and the ability to follow themselves around the board for critiques. The user finds the platform easy to use and appreciates the hidden features.

Text:
I have created a Creative Hack workshop template which I use to help teams and clients come up with ideas 
Ill also use Miro for other team tasks in which multiple people need to make inputs 
Its helpful for capturing a large amount of information in a little amount time and ultimately making sense of those inputs
I describe Miro as an Adobe Illustrator Group Chat I love the drag and drop flexibility of it and ease of use which allows me to capture ideas and feedback in real time Even when Im working with large groups of people the tool enables me to synthesize conversations and sharebacks in a way that captures the essence of a meeting
I have a few small feedback options for Miro 
 
1 For some reason I am forced to put a password on a board when I make it publically editable It didnt used to be like this and I find it annoying that I have to do that every time I end up just saying miroboard for everything 
 
2 When I invite outside of my org participants to join a board Via the UX they often think they have to sign up to view the board which leads to time lost in the session correcting them and getting them to the board as a guest quickly 
 
3 Not sure if this is still the case but I wish I could give people outside of my team permission to lock objects I work across teams so sometimes Im unable to lock assets on colleagues boards and vice versa
nn_summary: Users appreciate Miro for its ease of use, real-time collaboration, and ability to capture ideas effectively. However, they face issues with forced password protection on public boards, confusing UX for inviting external participants, and limited permission options for locking objects across teams.

Text:
Figma helps us maximize our small team and bandwidth by allowing us to design and work asynchronously We can create and iterate quickly ultimately delivering better product experiences and marketing initiatives faster  which is critical for a startup
Figma is most helpful for getting everyone on the team quickly with a visual realization of a campaign creative asset or even clickable prototype for sales pitches Organization is logical comment and approval notifications get attention and are simple to use overall intuitive platform
It would be nice to see different help articles and tools based on user sophistication and comfort level with the product
nn_summary: User appreciates the infinite canvas, voting, stickers, and rich diagramming tools in Figma, as well as multiple app integration, allowing them to use it as their primary productivity tool. They also appreciate the lack of a private space in the enterprise version, which only allows them to keep documents for themselves.

Text:
FigJam is solving the problem of communicating about technical system layouts with people who are not accustomed to verbally processing such layouts
FigJam makes creating diagrams and flowcharts very easy In my job I often need visual aids to explain technical systems and I need to create those aids more or less on the fly FigJam has been a lifesaver in that regard
My only complaints about FigJam are very small the biggest of which is that I wish it were simpler to create multiple wire attachment points on one side of a shape using a snaptogrid alignment There are times when I need 4 discrete wires running into one side of a shape and I dont necessarily want them all going to the central point
nn_summary: Users appreciate Figma for its ease of use and advanced features, which facilitate collaboration on process changes, improvements, and prioritization planning. However, they suggest adding extra snap points on shapes to improve alignment and connection lines.

Text:
Announcements in the world of AI today
Anthropic expands Claudes context window to 100000
Stability AIs new texttoanimation tool
Meta introduces the AI sandbox
Airtable unveils Airtable AI
Heres the rundown on everything you need to know
1 Anthropic revolutionizes Claude AI
Anthropic is boosting Claude their AI model by expanding its context window from a mere 9000 tokens to a whopping 100000 tokens
Claude can now analyze and interpret not just a few pages but hundreds 
The model could digest and analyze the entire text of The Great Gatsby in less than a minute 
This puts OpenAIs GPT4 and its 32k context window currently in beta in the dust 
2 Stability AIs texttoanimation tool
Stability AI just unveiled a powerful texttoanimation tool called Stable Animation SDK
Users can generate animations from text images or video combined with text 
3 Meta unveils generative AI for advertisers
Meta just introduced the AI Sandbox a playground for advertisers to try new generative AIpowered ad tools 
badimon photoroom_app figma Have you approached Meta

Text:
_Dave__White_ and I are excited to open source our power tool for interacting w LLMs Flux
Flux allows you to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel
Try it out at  
Fluxs tree structure lets you
 Get a wider variety of creative responses
 Test out different prompts with the same shared context
 Use inconsistencies to identify where the model is uncertain 
Flux also
 Has a robust set of keyboard shortcuts
 Allows setting the system message and editing GPT messages
 Autosaves to local storage
 Uses the OpenAI API directly
 Is open source and MIT licensed
Bug reports amp PRs welcome on Github 
Flux has been a major boost to our workflows and we hope it can do the same for you
Thank you to repligate for inspiring us with Loom ctjlewis for maintaining the awesome openaistreams library Flux is built on and of course _yangyou for her brilliant designs and feedback
PS This is only a bare bones version of what we imagine Flux could become
If youre interested in working with us on Flux or _Dave__White_s new game  wed love to talk w you
Reach out via DM or at t11s EMAIL_ADDRESS 
We have been working on an LLM collaboration tool using ceramicnetworks ComposeDB and of course flux 
Think of figma for prompt design

I first came across it during an online course and fell in love with it So I adopted it for my teams working from home Now we are pretty much back in the office but its still my go to We all sit around a massive table to collab and ideate and its all captured in real time on the board I find it really aesthetically pleasing which helps and whatever I need there is a template for it or something that can be tweaked
The infinity of the boards is excellent  the templates tools colours simplicity of navigation and its super intuitive so you dont have to learn loads of new stuff to use it I love you can bring people to you  I love the tutorials I love Miroverses
When I have invited people to join my team they inevitably love it and go off to create their own which results in one of my boards being disabled to its a bit of a faff to sling them out of my team copy the content to a new board and then get my board back

Text:
Documenting information in diagramsmaps helps the team visualize complex information architecture and align on foundations 
Sketching ideas in low fidelity increases our time to value at early design stages by allowing us to validate concepts before investing in highfidelity visualizations Having a space to collaborate on these lowfidelity designs makes the validation process more efficient and consolidates the thinking 
Using FigJam to share information with less designsavvy coworkers offers a friendly way to collect and organize inspiration or audits
FigJam makes it easy for me to sketch ideas map information in diagrams and collaborate with others Theres just enough design functionality to bring concepts to life without getting lost in the details Additional tools make workshops or brainstorming sessions fun and easy for my nondesigner colleagues to pick up I love having access to communitymade templates and graphics for inspiration
I wish participants could be invited to edit files without having a licensed seat I have run interactive workshops with participants who do not regularly use the tool and getting folks proper access in these cases is a bit tricky In cases where I have colleagues who need temporary access to files I use open sessions but need to reopen them each time the colleague requires edit access
nn_summary: Users appreciate Miro as a common platform for collaboration and visualization, which helps in daily presentations and organizing Agile events. However, they suggest improving the pen functionality for a smoother writing experience and propose the addition of a touchpad for more natural drawing

Text:
_Dave__White_ and I are excited to open source our power tool for interacting w LLMs Flux
Flux allows you to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel
Try it out at  
Fluxs tree structure lets you
 Get a wider variety of creative responses
 Test out different prompts with the same shared context
 Use inconsistencies to identify where the model is uncertain 
Flux also
 Has a robust set of keyboard shortcuts
 Allows setting the system message and editing GPT messages
 Autosaves to local storage
 Uses the OpenAI API directly
 Is open source and MIT licensed
Bug reports amp PRs welcome on Github 
Flux has been a major boost to our workflows and we hope it can do the same for you
Thank you to repligate for inspiring us with Loom ctjlewis for maintaining the awesome openaistreams library Flux is built on and of course _yangyou for her brilliant designs and feedback
PS This is only a bare bones version of what we imagine Flux could become
If youre interested in working with us on Flux or _Dave__White_s new game  wed love to talk w you
Reach out via DM or at t11s EMAIL_ADDRESS 
We have been working on an LLM collaboration tool using ceramicnetworks ComposeDB and of course flux 
Think of figma for prompt design
nn_summary: Flux is an open-source power tool for interacting with LLMs, allowing users to generate multiple completions per prompt in a tree structure and explore the best ones in parallel. It offers a variety of creative responses, tests different prompts with shared context, and identifies model uncertainties. Flux also features keyboard shortcuts, system message editing, autosaving, and direct use of the OpenAI API. The creators are open to collaboration and are working on an LLM collaboration tool using Ceramic Network's ComposeDB and Flux, similar to Figma for prompt design.
